questions.question_text_1: What of the following is the primary objective of a CSRF token?
question_texts: What of the following is the primary objective of a CSRF token?

options.option_text: To validate that the request comes from the authenticated user
To store the user's password securely

questions.question_text_1: What is the correct sequence of steps to update the state in Vuex when handling an asynchronous operation?
question_texts: What is the correct sequence of steps to update the state in Vuex when handling an asynchronous operation?

options.option_text: State → Dispatch an action → Commit a mutation → State change
Dispatch an action → Commit a mutation → State change
Commit a mutation → Dispatch an action → State change
State change → Commit a mutation → Dispatch an action

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you are developing an application for millions of users that will perform intensive data analysis and return the results asynchronously. Arrange the following set of actions/operations to achieve an efficient and scalable design.  I) Save the result to a database II) Invoke a callback URL III) Queue the analysis job

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements about Redis is true?
question_texts: Which of the following statements about Redis is true?

options.option_text: Redis is a relational database that uses SQL for querying data.
Redis is an in-memory data structure store, commonly used as a database,cache, and message broker.
Redis can only store string data types and does not support complex datastructures like lists or sets.
Redis cannot handle numerous operations per second.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following scenarios is an example of a Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attack?
question_texts: Which of the following scenarios is an example of a Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attack?

options.option_text: A user receives an email containing a link to a phishing site that asks for theirlogin credentials.
A user clicks on a malicious link while logged into their bank account, andwithout their knowledge, a money transfer request is sent to the bank's server using the user'sauthenticated session.
A hacker uses a brute-force attack to guess the password of a user's onlineaccount.
A user is tricked into downloading and installing malware that steals theirsensitive information.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about webhooks?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about webhooks?

options.option_text: Webhooks use HTTP requests to communicate events from one service toanother.
Webhooks require the recipient service to periodically poll the sender forupdates.
Webhooks are typically implemented using HTTP POST requests.
Webhooks guarantee that events will be delivered in order and exactly once.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding javascript?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding javascript?

options.option_text: Function declarations are hoisted along with their definitions.
Variable declarations with var are hoisted with their initializations.
let and const declarations are hoisted to the top of their block but remainuninitialized until execution reaches the declaration.
Only function declarations are hoisted, not function definition.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following scenarios are best suited for using Celery tasks?
question_texts: Which of the following scenarios are best suited for using Celery tasks?

options.option_text: Handling real-time user interactions on a website.
Sending out periodic email notifications to users.
Generating and displaying dynamic content on a web page.
Performing long-running data processing tasks in the background.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is/are true regarding webhooks and server sent events (SSE)?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is/are true regarding webhooks and server sent events (SSE)?

options.option_text: Webhooks are typically used for server-to-server communication, while SSE isused for server-to-client communication.
Webhooks require the client to maintain an open connection to receiveupdates, while SSE does not.
Webhooks are initiated by the server, while SSE connections are initiated bythe client.
SSE supports bidirectional communication, whereas webhooks do not.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are true about Server-Sent Events (SSE)?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are true about Server-Sent Events (SSE)?

options.option_text: SSE connections are established using HTTP.
SSE supports bidirectional communication between client and server.
SSE automatically switches to web socket if the connection is successful.
SSE is suitable for sending updates to multiple clients simultaneously.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding long and short polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding long and short polling?

options.option_text: A webhook is the same as short polling.
The short polling can be used to know the state of an asynchronous task, andtrigger an action if the task gets completed.
The long polling cannot be achieved using HTTP protocol.
Long Polling can be used to achieve real time communication.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Modern Application Development II"** exam, along with **key equations** (where applicable) and **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **1. Core Topics & Concepts** ### **A. Web Security** #### **1. CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)** - **Objective**: Validate that requests come from authenticated users (not malicious sites). - **Mechanism**: CSRF tokens are embedded in forms/headers and validated server-side. - **Attack Example**: - User clicks a malicious link while logged into their bank → unauthorized transfer occurs via their authenticated session. - **Mitigation**: - Use CSRF tokens (e.g., Django’s `{% csrf_token %}`). - SameSite cookies (restrict cookie sending to same-site requests). #### **2. CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)** - **Default Behavior**: Browsers block fetch calls to origins differing from the page’s origin (protocol + domain + port). - **Allowed Origins**: - Same origin (e.g., `https://example.com` → `https://example.com/subdir`). - Explicitly permitted via `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header. - **Key Headers**: - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: Specifies allowed origins (e.g., `*` or `https://trusted.com`). - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`: Allowed HTTP methods (e.g., `GET, POST`). #### **3. Secure Storage** - **`localStorage` vs. `sessionStorage`**: - `localStorage`: Persists across sessions (until cleared). - `sessionStorage`: Cleared when the tab closes. - **Security Risk**: Both are vulnerable to XSS (avoid storing sensitive data). - **Methods**: - `setItem(key, value)`, `getItem(key)`, `removeItem(key)`, `clear()`. --- ### **B. Asynchronous JavaScript** #### **1. Promises & Async/Await** - **Promise States**: - `Pending` → `Fulfilled` (resolved) or `Rejected`. - **Chaining**: - `.then()`: Handles fulfillment. - `.catch()`: Handles rejection. - `.finally()`: Executes regardless of outcome. - **Async/Await**: - `async` functions return promises. - `await` pauses execution until the promise settles. #### **2. Closures** - **Definition**: A function retains access to its lexical scope even when executed outside it. - **Example**: ```javascript function parent() { let a = 2; return function child() { console.log(a); }; } const closure = parent(); // `a` is retained in `child`'s scope. closure(); // Output: 2 ``` #### **3. `setTimeout`/`setInterval`** - **Behavior**: - `setTimeout(callback, delay)`: Executes `callback` once after `delay` ms. - `setInterval(callback, delay)`: Executes `callback` repeatedly every `delay` ms. - **Closure Pitfall**: - Loops with `setTimeout` may reference the final loop variable value (use `let` or IIFE to capture values). #### **4. Event Loop** - **Phases**: 1. **Call Stack**: Executes synchronous code. 2. **Microtask Queue**: Processes promises (`then/catch/finally`). 3. **Macrotask Queue**: Handles `setTimeout`, `setInterval`, I/O. - **Order**: Microtasks > Macrotasks. --- ### **C. State Management (Vuex)** #### **1. Vuex Flow** 1. **Dispatch an Action** (async operations, e.g., API calls). 2. **Commit a Mutation** (synchronous state updates). 3. **State Change** triggers reactive updates in components. - **Key Methods**: - `this.$store.dispatch('actionName', payload)` - `commit('mutationName', payload)` #### **2. Vue Reactivity** - **`data()`**: Reactive properties (tracked by Vue). - **`computed`**: Cached derived data. - **`v-model`**: Two-way binding (e.g., ``). --- ### **D. Caching & Performance** #### **1. Redis** - **Use Cases**: - In-memory cache (e.g., `@cache.cached(timeout=60)` in Flask). - Session storage, message brokering (Pub/Sub). - **Data Structures**: Strings, lists, sets, hashes, sorted sets. #### **2. Flask-Caching** - **Decorators**: - `@cache.cached(timeout=180)`: Caches function results for 180 seconds. - `@cache.memoize`: Caches based on function arguments. - **Backends**: SimpleMemory, Redis, Memcached. #### **3. HTTP Caching Headers** - **`Cache-Control`**: - `max-age=3600`: Cache for 1 hour. - `no-store`: Never cache. - `no-cache`: Revalidate with server before using. - **`Expires`**: Absolute expiry time (e.g., `Expires: Thu, 31 Dec 2023 23:59:59 GMT`). --- ### **E. Real-Time Communication** #### **1. Webhooks** - **Definition**: Server-to-server HTTP callbacks (e.g., GitHub → Slack on push). - **Characteristics**: - **Unidirectional**: Sender → Receiver. - **Event-Driven**: Triggered by events (e.g., payment success). - **HTTP POST**: Typically used for payload delivery. - **Example**: ```python @app.route('/webhook', methods=['POST']) def webhook(): data = request.json print("Received:", data) return "OK", 200 ``` #### **2. Server-Sent Events (SSE)** - **Use Case**: Server → Client updates (e.g., live scores). - **Features**: - **Unidirectional**: Server pushes updates. - **HTTP-Based**: Uses `text/event-stream` MIME type. - **Auto-Reconnect**: Client reconnects if the connection drops. - **Example**: ```javascript const eventSource = new EventSource('/sse-endpoint'); eventSource.onmessage = (e) => console.log(e.data); ``` #### **3. WebSockets** - **Bidirectional**: Full-duplex communication (e.g., chat apps). - **Protocol**: `ws://` or `wss://` (secure). - **Example**: ```javascript const socket = new WebSocket('wss://example.com/chat'); socket.onmessage = (e) => console.log(e.data); ``` #### **4. Polling vs. Long Polling vs. SSE vs. WebSockets** | Method | Direction | Protocol | Real-Time | Overhead | |-----------------|-----------------|-----------|-----------|----------------| | **Polling** | Client → Server | HTTP | ❌ No | High | | **Long Polling**| Client → Server | HTTP | ✅ Yes | Medium | | **SSE** | Server → Client | HTTP | ✅ Yes | Low | | **WebSockets** | Bidirectional | WS/WSS | ✅ Yes | Low (after handshake) | --- ### **F. Task Queues (Celery)** - **Use Cases**: - Background tasks (e.g., sending emails, data processing). - Periodic tasks (e.g., cron jobs). - **Components**: - **Broker**: Message queue (Redis, RabbitMQ). - **Worker**: Executes tasks. - **Result Backend**: Stores task results (e.g., Redis). - **Example**: ```python @celery.task def send_email(user_id): user = User.query.get(user_id) mail.send(...) ``` --- ### **G. Vue.js** #### **1. Dynamic Class Binding** - **Syntax**: ```html
``` or ```html
``` #### **2. Vue Router** - **Dynamic Routes**: ```javascript { path: '/profile/:id', component: Profile } ``` - **Accessing Params**: ```javascript this.$route.params.id // e.g., "1235" ``` --- ### **H. HTTP & APIs** #### **1. REST vs. Webhooks** | Feature | REST API | Webhooks | |---------------|------------------------|---------------------------| | **Initiator** | Client polls server | Server pushes to client | | **Efficiency**| High latency | Low latency (event-driven)| | **Use Case** | Fetch data on demand | Notify on events (e.g., payments) | #### **2. Pub/Sub** - **Definition**: Message queue pattern where publishers send messages to topics, and subscribers receive them. - **Example (Redis)**: ```python # Publisher redis.publish("channel", "Hello, subscribers!") # Subscriber pubsub = redis.pubsub() pubsub.subscribe("channel") for message in pubsub.listen(): print(message["data"]) ``` --- ## **2. Key Equations (Mathematics/Algorithms)** ### **A. Time Complexity** | Operation | Complexity | |--------------------------|------------| | Redis `GET`/`SET` | O(1) | | Array `push`/`pop` | O(1) | | Array `shift`/`unshift` | O(n) | | Binary Search | O(log n) | ### **B. Caching Hit/Miss** - **Hit Rate**: \[ \text{Hit Rate} = \frac{\text{Number of Hits}}{\text{Total Requests}} \] - **Cache Invalidation**: Strategies like TTL (Time-to-Live) or manual invalidation. --- ## **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: Web Security Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Security] --> B[CSRF] A --> C[CORS] A --> D[XSS] A --> E[Secure Storage] B --> B1[CSRF Tokens] B --> B2[SameSite Cookies] C --> C1[Origin Policy] C --> C2[Access-Control-Allow-Origin] D --> D1[Sanitize Input] D --> D2[Avoid innerHTML] E --> E1[localStorage] E --> E2[sessionStorage] E --> E3[HttpOnly Cookies] ``` ### **Graph 2: Asynchronous JavaScript** ```mermaid graph TD A[Asynchronous JS] --> B[Promises] A --> C[Async/Await] A --> D[Event Loop] A --> E[Closures] B --> B1[.then] B --> B2[.catch] B --> B3[.finally] D --> D1[Call Stack] D --> D2[Microtask Queue] D --> D3[Macrotask Queue] E --> E1[Lexical Scope] E --> E2[IIFE] ``` ### **Graph 3: Real-Time Communication** ```mermaid graph TD A[Real-Time Communication] --> B[Webhooks] A --> C[SSE] A --> D[WebSockets] A --> E[Polling] B --> B1[Server-to-Server] B --> B2[HTTP POST] C --> C1[Server-to-Client] C --> C2[text/event-stream] D --> D1[Bidirectional] D --> D2[ws:// Protocol] E --> E1[Short Polling] E --> E2[Long Polling] ``` ### **Graph 4: State Management (Vuex)** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vuex] --> B[State] A --> C[Actions] A --> D[Mutations] A --> E[Getters] B --> B1[Single Source of Truth] C --> C1[Async Operations] C --> C2[dispatch] D --> D1[Sync State Updates] D --> D2[commit] E --> E1[Computed Properties] ``` ### **Graph 5: Caching Strategies** ```mermaid graph TD A[Caching] --> B[Client-Side] A --> C[Server-Side] A --> D[CDN] B --> B1[localStorage] B --> B2[sessionStorage] C --> C1[Redis] C --> C2[Flask-Caching] C --> C3[Memcached] D --> D1[Edge Caching] D --> D2[TTL] ``` ### **Graph 6: Task Queues (Celery)** ```mermaid graph TD A[Celery] --> B[Broker] A --> C[Worker] A --> D[Result Backend] B --> B1[Redis] B --> B2[RabbitMQ] C --> C1[Concurrency] C --> C2[Task Retries] D --> D1[Redis] D --> D2[Database] ```
